author: JakeTB
content:
Hey all. Just wanted to say how much I appreciate this community and attest to the quality of conversation here.

I put in my resignation notice at the day job today, and will be transitioning to music full-time in May. I genuinely don’t believe I could have done it without this place. You all challenge me in the best ways, and have helped me grow tremendously as a person and a professional.

I still don’t have it all sorted out, and I’m still fervently pursuing mentorship in any form I can find, but for now the work is paying the bills; something I thought I’d never be able to say.

Thank you all for being generous with your hard-earned wisdom. It really does make a difference.

(Sorry, got a bit sappy there 😅)

author: oaklandmatt
Slow Hand
content:
Hey @everyone. Our resident mixer and engineer @cian riordan made a badass post on Friday about his approach to mixing live drums. He even shared his template; great guy that he is. Did you catch it?

If not, which channel did he post it in? The hell if *I* know! Luckily we no longer have to trawl the Discord logs to locate it. His entire essay is now being hosted on the newly minted *Resources* section of the LWMR website.

In the coming weeks we’ll be filling this section in with some of the very best posts and nuggets of wisdom that have come through the LWMR server so far. author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
...completely unrelated to anything  but on my mind this morning

Something I've said here (maybe too) often is that approaching the work in a loving way is a real unlock. Love being a quaity of a attention, a way of meeting things. It might not be obvious but it can start small and grow out embracing many more aspects of what we do

I mastered an album a few months back for a phenomenal indie artist, @Rob Domos and I both absolutely loved the music and the overall experience. The artist's team came back this week with a last minute request to remaster what was probably my favorite track with an added feature from a legacy artist. It's kind of mind bending how much better it is

Rob and I spent some time yesterday just appreciating that someone (the artist, manager, A&R?) actually thought up the idea of this feature and made it happen. I was so content with what it was but someone somewhere was like *"you know what would be sick ..."* and made it real. And now the world gets to receive something beyond what we could have imagined, something we didn't even know we needed

Just focussing our attention on that for 2 mins in the hall yesterday made the day better and put some gas in the tank. There are so many challenges in what we do, it really helps to take time to focus attention on the jewels strewn everywhere too. They are not always immediately obvious

author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Happy New Year People of Discord, I’ve been quiet on here this last while. An intense end of year run into a trip

I’ve had more time away from work this last few weeks than I have in almost a decade. And it’s been an interesting experience 

Here are some first draft no edit  questions from 30,000 feet to get some conversation started. Pick any or all to answer, restate the question at the top of your reply so people know wth you are talking about

- Why make records now?

- How do you think about the tension between or overlap of fun/play and the seriousness of the work?

- What do you think is holding you back in your record making life? And what would a smart trusted friend close to your work say is holding you back?

- What does winning really look like? Is it  a comfortable got the gear/schedule under control/critical acclaim or more like continued new and risky challenges

- Speaking of risk, what does taking risks look like for you at this stage in your journey?

- What happens if you get everything you want?

- How will you give back in 2024?

- What’s one thing about how you approach the work that you are hoping to change in 2024?

- What are you most excited about in music right now? And what are you most afraid of?

- What do you think you in 5 years would tell you now if you could?

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was having a conversation with a buddy of mine that has a child with Cerebral Palsy a while back. I’d said that it must be challenging, and he told me a story I’ll never forget. He said “you know that old bit about being able to go to a party and dump your most challenging life issue in the middle of the room?” (I didn’t)
“Basically everyone goes to a party and you’re allowed to leave your biggest challenge there, as long as you leave with someone else’s biggest challenge. And at the end of the night everyone realizes they’d rather go home with the challenge they came with after seeing everybody else’s”. 
The lesson of that has really stuck with me. Our lives tend to be better than we realize once we’ve seen what others ACTUALLY have to deal with, not just the tip of the iceberg they show to the world.

author: kieronmenzies
content: On the topic of communication, I know it goes without saying (pretty sure we're all guilty of this) but it's always worth mentioning in case there are any younger impressionable minds reading this. Older unimpressionable minds may as well read it too. Don't forget to communicate with yourself. Week in and week out, I don't know how many times I plug my ears and go "lalala I'm not listening" when my body starts throwing terms at me like fatigue, exhaustion, dehydrated, hungry, getting sick, underslept, stressed, depressed, fully sick, too much coffee, etc. At this point, maybe it's time to listen and do yourself a favor because in the long run, every favor done for you is also a favor to your family, your community and your clients.

author: popaganda.
content:
You’re gut’s probably right about this situation, but I also feel like you’re saying “everything isn’t the way I want it to be right now so I’m gonna bail.” Collaboration is really hard and nobody gets it 💯 their way, and it sounds like you feel like your efforts are wasted if the aesthetic is fucked. 
But no effort towards making good music is a waste. If that were the case me and a lot of the folks here would be complete losers, but we’re not. We’re actually better for having worked on things that we’d never share willingly.
Is this really a reason to bail? I’m not saying it isn’t. But aesthetics are really subjective. Are you saying your finger’s on the pulse of your generation’s aesthetic taste? Is there room for differences? Also, it sounds like your friend wrote the songs and is the frontman, and you are producing, playing bass, and mixing. Why are you so attached to the visual aspect of it when your role is more support rather than the face of the project?

author: bobby k
content:
Most of my years in music have felt like groundwork-laying years. Just because your credits playlist isn’t looking the way you’d like doesn’t mean that growth wasn’t happening. I would challenge you to reflect on where you started 2025 and where you are now and take inventory of what growth or lessons you experienced. 

The most rewarding bits of this year for me wouldn’t make sense to post about. Paid off my first business loan. Improved the efficiency of signal flow in my studio. Learned to fix some gear. Stood up for myself in a hard conversation with some assholes trying to rip me off. Got out of the UAD ecosystem. 

None of that I’m posting about or adding to a playlist, but it feels just as essential (or more) to my business than the songs that got released.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
On the food analogy:

Making food that is nutritious is not hard. A pile of kale, a bowl of plain beans, an avocado, maybe a fish, and a glass of water and you've got nutrition.

Making the first bite taste amazing isn't hard either. Add a ton of salt sugar and oil, maybe fry it. That'll hit 98% of people's taste buds hard immediately.

The challenge is not doing either, but doing both. 

Same is true for music.

First listen great, 1000th listen great, and have that effect on the most number of people. That's my favorite kind of music.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Love the whole conversation above. 

One thing to consider with the whole “people hire me for my taste” thing is that it’s important to have not only a refined palate, but also a broad enough one to be collaborating. 

I’ve worked with extremely talented people who don’t have the breadth to apply their skills to something even slightly outside of their *exact* preference, and I perceive that as being to their detriment. 

If you want to be a professional chef and you make incredible arrabbiata but begrudgingly phone it in with alfredo, you’re going to have a pretty poor career telling Italian restaurants that you’re the right guy for arrabbiata and the wrong guy for alfredo. That’s niching down a little too hard a little too early.

I think it’s our job to find the essence within something and maximally bring that essence out. Often these “taste mismatch” issues come across to me as missing that essence within the thing you’re working on and trying to make it something that it essentially isn’t. ie. A wannabe Max Martin working with a wannabe mitski and the producer complaining that the artist’s suggestions are making the production hashy and the artist complaining that the producer’s production choices don’t convey enough emotion. 

It’s talking past each-other and not really collaborating. You aren’t learning to truly love what your partner loves, which IMO is frankly a big part of the job.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There's a term I came across years ago (cannot recall the source) that's always stuck with me. The writer made mention of people they called "geniuses of everyday living."

They were referring to the uncelebrated people among us who may be living quiet lives of private accomplishment. Not chasing after lofty or conspicuous goals, or a grand ambition. Perhaps these people are satisfied raising a family, or existing in their community to the best of their ability. Or perhaps they are absorbed in a far more humble pursuit and are completely satisfied in their day-to-day efforts.

That sounds like something to aspire to. And for those who might qualify I wonder how much intelligence or wisdom play a role in such a thing.

author: Rob Domos
content:
“Only fools want their own elevator”
This brings to mind a time when I introduced a dude I used to live with to a good friend of mine who had multiple platinum credits, and my friend proceeded to explain his whole process of vocal production to the guy I lived with for a couple of hours straight. Afterwards, my then-roommate said to me “why did he tell me all of that? Now I don’t need him anymore! What an idiot!” And at that moment, I lost all desire to ever work with that dude again.  

Life is largely about family, love, connection, collaboration, etc. without that, what’s the point?

I’m not sure there are any answers to these questions 

 The great paradox of record making is that you have to trust your compass implicitly but as soon as someone else says “North is this way!” You need to be open to that

Add to that that you and your collaborators are literally creating the terrain as you go it’s hard to be definitive about any of it

author: Chase H
content:
@franc.castillejos 
I’m in Milwaukee which is by no means an LA or a Nashville.

I’m getting closer to being able to go full time mixing and doing some recording/producing in this small town by honestly just going out to shows of artist I enjoy and networking with them on a personal level, not even bringing up me mixing or recording for them.

Fulltime will  mean different things to different people but to me that means being able to support myself, my future wife (I get married in May) and our future children being able to stay at home full time without my wife having to work.

I haven’t worked on anything big but I love Music and being able to be in service of someone else putting out their vision.

I was close to moving to Nashville last year as I have a good amount of connects but for my life it wasn’t the right thing,

This may not be worth much because I’m by no means a heavy hitter engineer like some of the people here but maybe it’s a good idea for you  to DEFINE what success is to you, and then work backwards from there.

Wherever you end up I’m sure there will be a community of artists that you gel with and over time can work with and help them present their art

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes. If you ever encounter someone who is giving you clear, honest feedback about something *and* is qualified to do so keep them close. That can apply to creative work, relationships, or other collaborations. I highly value those people when I meet them.

The feedback may painful to hear, but if it is constructive and presented in the right spirit it is worth it's weight in gold. We want to run *towards* that. The closer that we can get to tightening the feedback loop between our actions and their consequences the better off we'll all be.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I would say that true art (by the broadest definition) defies a recipe. Art that you can give a step by step instruction for is a product, not art. That almost mystical nature of discovery, saying the unsaid, and found connection in "true art" separates it from things that are just "manufactured"

So in the spirit of my post a few weeks ago about there being no master key I think the IG video could be viewed as "some ways to solve some challenges" rather than the one size fits all recipe. I loved the energy and think it will meet some super motivated subset of people in it's audeince that are pumped by it

I've done projects from complete bootstrap lifters, to "working class" & "organic" label signings to trust fund kids. All can be frameworks for great art, but none guarantee more of the special stuff IMO

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pretty damn frequently. Producers moreso than mixers.

When I find a record that resonates with me I'm very full-immersion and I'll devour as much of their adjacent body of work as I can. I'll start scrutinizing the record credits and pulling on threads as I see them. I really try to fill in the context around the record by identifying all collaborators, timelines, interviews they gave around that time, published works, etc. I've got a huge appetite for that thing.

I really love reading books written by producers. The more old school the better. Phil Ramone's *Making Records* is a great one. That guy is a class act. Quincy Jones has both an autobiography *and* a book specifically on producing. The latter is a great no-shortcuts look at what it takes to be great. I enjoyed Daniel Lanois' *Soul Mining*, since he's got a very thoughtful immersive way of making records and working with artists that I appreciate.

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ohmigosh. That reminds me of a time I was making small talk with a stranger and mentioned that I was a musician. They said “Oh cool! Who’s your favorite *American Idol* contestant?”

And in that moment my brain shut down completely. I was blindsided by the question. I couldn’t even begin to formulate an answer because I couldn’t make sense of where to start. 

It was *so* outside the realm of what I think of as music, and I realized that by them asking the question that they must also have a *very* different conceptualization of the music industry. My brain shut down and ouput an *error* message.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
only point I disagree with is music (art) not being essential.  and I think in a lot of ways ppl not seeing it as so is a key problem overall. 

no its not food but we're so used to having access to some form of it (good or bad, to our taste or not) that I think it gets undervalued overall. (obviously outliers exist)

I've literally seen art save lives. mental and emotional health is a necessity and music (even sound in general) I find is a key element. 

a ridiculous amount of cultures (read:indigenous) placed immense value on the art in their culture..often as part of their spiritual beliefs. even colonists co-opted and modified songs to allow conquests though culture more easily.

I think accessibility makes us think art isn't a necessity. it is. a lot of us would probably have lost our minds at this point (and I've seen that happen) if we didn't have it to lean on for various aspects. I'm not saying it should be #1 priority but I do think the inherent value we (the world) give art can directly affect how we value other things 

it's also the source of community and support for a lot of people and we are community based beings at our core  (though we can seperate to some extent).

the mindset things is also v interesting. being from Haiti I see American payment mindsets and European (a lot of both out there) and there's also more traditional ones that are more based in community - usually ones that survived colonialism to some extent. see:taino culture (mostly survived in pr, almost non existent in the other islands now). those are more focused on everyone getting there part fairly. the work is for the community not for yourself. while juxtaposition w the other mindset has flipped some folks' wayof working a lot of them are fine as is.

there's  o clear solution to the value of art thing. diff fields and different positions have to find ways of presenting value but I see that as a Consequence of the mentality we've adopted not a solution

author: jantrit
content:
I’m going  fail to properly put this into words but the ability to extrapolate and have an understanding of the learning process/ be driven to take that journey. One example would be this, someone comes in fresh expecting you to spoon feed them the knowledge, that’s not super helpful. But someone comes in and can say, “oh that’s a Patchbay, can you show me how it works”. You can teach those people anything. The desire and hunger to learn on their own and the ability to acquire knowledge for themselves has been a huge divide I’ve noticed in the intern/ college community.  

One time we were setting up a session and I was explaining to our intern my thoughts about which headphones we’d give to each station. (This pair has better bass, we’ll give them to the bass player. These are open back we’ll give them to the horn section so they can blend better) The very next session without having to mention it, she had placed the same headphones in the same places AND ALSO she then took that info and made a the judgement that we’d give the nicest most comfy pair to the vocalist. That’s what I mean about extrapolation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good way to summarize the benefit of Andrej's approach here is by looking at two different ways to go about learning how a frog works: 

1) You can dissect a frog to learn about it. You observe the long legs, the muscles, the skin, the eyes, the respiratory system, etc. You see it's strengths and you see it's weaknesses and you draw your conclusions from there. This would be the top-down learning approach. It's good at describing what already *is*. 

Or...

2) You build/design a frog from scratch. You will quickly come to understand why things *have* to be the way they are. You realize that all of the evolutionary "choices" about a frog's physiology are simply the best possible compromises, given the pressures of the environment, the availability of resources, and the limits of physics. By building it yourself you will come to perceive all of the invisible challenges and "solved" problems that were required to make an organism that will simply survive, much less thrive.

This firsthand experience of building the thing will actually make you an expert because you've done the hard work and experienced it for yourself. You took ten paths to failure and made every mistake before settling on a a non-obvious compromise that allows you to balance it against every other factor. You understand *why* it needs to be that way.

This knowledge will make you robust and flexible, whereas top-down knowledge is more superficial and brittle. If the conditions of your subject change and the model you understand is no longer relevant then you're in a far more precarious place than someone who's built something from the ground up.

author: LAPhill
content:
With any passion that becomes a career, a certain amount of the mystique is bound to wear off once you become one of the magic makers. To use your analogy, dating a new girl feels different than a year in, vs. being married, vs. having a family. It's absolutely normal for the type of love you have for music to evolve over time and repetition.

I kind of doubt that earning money from music is the root cause of your feelings. But it might be affecting how you encounter music. If it's all feeling too ordinary, then break the ordinary. Go listen to live music that's far away from anything you touch. Pick up an instrument you don't know how to play and get in a room with some friends and enjoy being bad, but exploring music like a child. 

The "quitting" thing often feels like something often born out of rough working experiences, or perhaps just too mundane. Bills have to get paid (burgers gotta get flipped) but perhaps you can balance those gigs with things that challenge and excite you, even if they're not particularly lucrative. 

tl;dr I think we all go through phases of questioning if the career is worth it, if not questioning our relationship with music itself, but in my experience, almost everyone comes out the other side after a bit of a mental reset.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Ultimately follow your gut - only you know what's right for you.

But I wanted to say for @cian riordan to mix a track for you I feel like you guys must have something good musically going there.  In my experience a big part of true collaboration is having to let go of some control of some parts of the whole thing.  Just putting out there you might be walking away from something really cool in the early stages because of a desire to control every aspect of the project.  It sounds like there are a lot of people that care a lot about the project to invest their time and energy and taste into it.

Again - you know everything you are feeling and the dynamics and if it's not worth it to you then absolutely walk away.  But maybe worth it to try and make the best of it for another few months and see where it leads?  If you are worried about how other people perceive the marketing/instagram can't you just explain you don't have anything to do with that end of the project?

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I honestly think you should sit with great headphones and listen to the album front to back. Try and absorb it like a complete art project with your full attention. He has spoken about deliberately creating something that you can't quite grab onto immediately, an album that exists in a liminal space between contemporary and vintage, between lofi and hi res, between genres.

If you sit with the album and listen with the understanding that everything you hear and experience is a choice from a single artist (rather than the multitude of collaborators for most contemporary albums), I think you can enjoy it a lot.

author: Rollmottle
content: The point isn't to tamp anybody's curiosity, it's to keep young record makers from wasting time on things that don't actually matter to the art of making records. A young record maker's bottleneck isn't their DAW choice. The discourse out there would have you believe your DAW choice, your plugins, the guitar bridge material, etc. are why you're not good enough yetl. Jon's mixes are incredible because of who he is, not because of the DAW he uses or what he believes about them. The kind of clip MWTM chose to highlight here simply feeds into the conflation of tools with results and are doing the broader community a disservice by leaning into it.

author: Rollmottle
content: Focusing on the things squarely within my control is the way I’ve learned to do it. Only I can choose where and how to focus my attention and energy. The "world" doesn't make me do or feel anything I don't choose to feel or do. This doesn’t mean tune out and become a cold-hearted sociopath. But we need to balance the inputs so we are maximally available to the pursuits and the community we will have an immediate impact on. The world doesn’t give a shit if I constantly bang on about <insert anything bad you can think of here>. But my wife or child or collaborator or co-worker certainly will. We have so much more control over our perceived realities than we give ourselves credit for. And it's our choice whether we indulge the negative.

author: cian riordan
content: Nail on the head. I think I had mentioned this in a previous post, but these days notes tend to come in real time -- via text messages, dropbox comments, or sometimes even thoughtful emails. I'll usually take a quick glance, but then dump everything into a note file so I have everything in one place when I sit to do the revision. This can be useful when you'll get a thread of notes like 1) I'm not sure about the drum sound, it feel so x... then 2) someone else will chime in saying I love the drums! I think x is the problem then 3) first person is hesitant and shrugs of their not, even though it may still bother them. That way I can try and string together some sort of move that will hopefully make everyone happy. If you're dealing with a band -- and you're producing/engineering -- you'll have had the benefit of seeing the dynamic. Sometimes you get some people that are more engaged and tweaky, others that are unsure of EVERYTHING, and then people that when they say something, they're usually right, as infrequent as that may be. This is very useful during mix notes time because you have context. If you're just getting flies flown to you and you've never met the band/artist, thats certainly a bit more of a challenge and will likely require more work on your end to smooth things out.

author: alecdibell2
content:
@absflores The bounces I send to clients are always labelled “in.prog” until we decide on the final mix.  It keeps things organized if they liked something about “in.prog1”, that we moved away from, and wanted to bring back in “in.prog3”.

I don’t send an in.prog until I feel just about done with the mix, or I want to ask the artist about their intention on a specific part of the track, before moving through that section of the mix. It’s mostly an organizational tool for me, and keeps the artist in the loop with the process being a collaboration

I Think people lift their noses at shows like these, not to look Down on contestants. But more so the premis of the show.  The over production, the false reactions, the comments from the hosts/judges. The whole over-dramatisation that a lot of us can see right through. Also the fact that it is a contest because of “music ain’t a contest dude, it’s art✌️”. 

I think that the comparison to McDonalds is good, not because it is fast food or “low quality” or whatever, but because it’s not a food business. It’s a real estate business that uses food as a by-product(you know what I mean). These programs are just “reality” shows using music as a by product.

Sure there are some good meals, but I’m sure some chefs would up their nose at people who think McDonald’s defines the culinary experience as a whole. The same way a lot of Music people May feel misinterpreted by people who’s only intake of music is through these programs. 


Sorry rant over, was just a long stream of thought that came as I wrote it 😅 

My fave to come out of one of those programs is probably Harry Styles. He keeps impressing the further he goes in his career! 😇

author: spectrummasters
content: @bobby k So way waaaaay back in the uk , when drum and bass and dubstep (and garage ) didn’t exist yet there were a few london based producers scattered about manipulating breakbeats like james browns funky drummer drum break , the amen drum break from the Winston brothers and the apache drum break . England had had breakbeat hardcore for a few years already (eg . Early early prodigy ) and then the British carribean community and others familiar with reggae and particularly the early 90s ragga scene in Jamaica , started fusing ragga acapellas and dub bass line motifs with hardcore ‘s drum breaks . This was pioneering and was referred to as future sounds  , back then the mode was established for U.K. street music producers to value “futuristic “ aka pioneering / unheard of / new sounds and rhythms .

author: Slow Hand
content:
Gosh, it can be so many things that endear me to an artist and it can be none of them. It's a slippery thing to grasp, but here I go:

**1. They have a well-defined vision for their art that I can observe them continually exploring.**
**2. If they present themselves as a public figure, what is the expression of their persona? **
Is it authentic? (I'm a real person)
Is it stylized? (a heightened version)
Is it larger than life? (I'm a God)
Is it mysterious? (Leave me alone)

**3. Their actions as a person**
What do they believe in?
What do they advocate for?
Does their sense of humor manifest in their art?
Do they have interests outside their music? Do they tie them into their art?

**4. How do I observe them confronting challenges?**
Do they swing big in their creative efforts?
Are they resourceful in how they execute?
Are they telling a story about these challenges?

These are all qualities that I like to observe in artists. Some artists will have all of them, some will have none of them, and that's alright.

author: Pio
content:
One thing I’ve liked about entering into the world of music, during the last decade, has been that social media has kind of made the world… bigger for me?

I love my local scene in Dublin and in Ireland. I’m proud of what we can do, what a lot of fantastic artists of all different kinds are doing from here. At the same time, I see the possibility of complacency, and how quick we are to presume that the lack of opportunities we perceive are due to how tough the industry is… rather than the other possibility. When I look on social media, the pure talent and skill on display across the world can be crippling to see, if you look at it through a kind of despair-ready lens. But I’ve found that it can actually be really powerful in a positive way too - i feel its challenged me to work to become better at my craft. To seek to perform not at a local level, but as a part of a global scene, and I feel that’s been really healthy for me.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
You're getting pretty granular with all this which can be useful, but might be worth zooming out a touch. The most meaningful collaborations I've had have been from me producing work that earns the respect and appreciation of my peers. The work itself is the alignment optimizer and the collaboration has almost always been downstream of that. I think its much harder to find alignment with 100 cold calls (which I've also tried). I think looking for a balance between producing music you really love and are proud of and cultivating a network of potential artists you would want to collaborate with is a good way of being. Which might be exactly what you're doing. Idk without more context.

Could be helpful to think of it like a conversation and maybe you need to make the first move. Have you tried commenting on other artists work you come across online that you find compelling? Not in a spammy juice the numbers kinda way but more of a conscious attitude towards how you choose to travel online. I see that all the time leading to collaboration between artists.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I actually *just* posted this in a #🎛gear-talk convo, but I'll elaborate in more detail:

I set annual themes for myself.  This year is the *Year of Intuition and Sensuality*.

The *intuition* aspect means that whenever an opportunity arises to do something I will challenge myself to dive right in and intuitively feel my way through it, rather than taking an overhead approach and charting everything out before I act. Don't second-guess. Just go for it.

I'm exceedingly good at planning and analysis, but I'm less comfortable with simply diving headfirst into something, getting messy, and figuring it out as I go. So this year is about me identifying opportunities to do so and hack away without premeditation (I've already got that in spades). Throw myself in and then dig myself out. It's a muscle I want to flex so that I can be more ambidextrous in my approach to situations.

The *sensuality* half is about being more in touch with my body. It's less about health or fitness and more about observing my body and following the sensations. Being more sensual. Whether it's exploring feelings of touch, scent, or flavor. Being attuned to how my body feels when I sing. Or how an instrument through an amp resonates in my body. Following those instincts. Dancing more. Anything that might fall under that umbrella.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Good question! If I were to list a few reasons:

- The government has invested in free or almost free music education for decades and decades, as well as financial support and grants for musicians
- Collaborative, non-hierarchical culture
- Trailblazers in the field that pay it forward
- A culture that cherishes English-speaking music and tries to understand it from a ESL POV, approaching music making with international export in mind

At this point there's so many institutions and traditions around it, it's embedded in the culture

author: Zach Hughes
content: Personally it saddens me to see the continued disregard of the value of accurate and transparent credits by those in music. There's a reason the issue of credits is so messed up in this industry. I believe it's part systems, part incentives, but is also part cultural. I have hope that we can honor the contributions of our collaborators and build trust based networks. I don't see a solution to credits coming from anywhere outside of our tent. We do a disservice to the next generation of engineers, producers, and artists every time we obfuscate who contributed what to any given project.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, it's hard to say what's best without a more holistic understanding of who you are and your circumstances, so I’m reluctant to offer any hard suggestions. Making a career in the music industry is what engineers would call a "wicked" problem. It's not something that has a repeatable solution, and what works for someone rarely works the same way for the next person.

That said, I see that you’re from Boston. I lived there for seven years, and the talent pool in that city is tremendous. I think if you found yourself back home in Boston it would be a worthwhile investment to integrate yourself into the scene of young musicians that are centered around the schools in the Back Bay like Berklee, NEC, and Boston Conservatory. There are some immensely talented, diverse, and creative people from all around the world based at those institutions and they all exist within 8 blocks of each other. It’s rare to have such a concentration of driven musicians all mingling amongst each other. This is a massive resource that you can tap into. They're *all* trying to make something great and explore what's possible.

It's a unique opportunity to discover collaborators, build relationships, earn experience in your craft, and build strong connections for the future as you grow alongside these people. On top of that, Boston has numerous recording studios where you can intern and assist. There’s a lot of experience to be gained working in a studio that simply won’t be taught to you in a recording program. Supplement that practical experience with hard work, and some book learning and you can do very well for yourself.

There’s more that I’m not touching-on, but I think if you ended up back in Boston it not be as much as a trade-off as you may think.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yes. The same way you do anything in life you want to get good at. Spend a shit load of time doing that thing. There really are no hacks or work arounds if you want to actually get good. An easy free way to do it is just learn as many songs as you can. If you want to really be proficient in the musical language I would recommend learning stuff by ear. It takes a lot longer than looking up tutorials or sheet music. But I promise you will develop your ears infinitely more. Specially in the beginning. Music is a language. Every human being learns to speak and converse before they learn how to spell and know the rules of grammar. Learning theory will only let you put names to sounds so that you can convey musical ideas to their people. Contrary to what a lot of people think, there are no rules, but there are a lot of conventions and traditions, but they keep changing and have lots of exceptions. Learning a shit ton of songs on whatever instrument you choose, will teach you what those conventions are and how to use them. 

In the beginning it’s good to just learn every song you like as well as you can, because it will help keep you motivated as you like the music. Then after a while you will probably want to branch out and try stuff you’ve never listened to or enjoyed before just to challenge yourself. 

The most musical people I know, are the people who wouldn’t know what to do with a Caugmented#9 but can listen to a song once and play it nearly perfectly, because their ears and musical language is so developed from playing a fuck lot of music and not spending time reading about it or watching endless tutorials.

author: spectrummasters
content: Wellllll, as the person who asked the opening question , re: marketing and perceived value, it did seem to open up a broad discussion with a lot of varied input . Wherever it got into any perceived sense of entitlement , was off track as the core of the question was about leveraging and better pay/benefits for the successful elite (nothing to do with people striving to get there ) . It wasn’t a question about working hard.....or having talent......or how to share a pie and how much pie there is ......that’s all a given in the original discussion I referenced that was between two Grammy winning engineers.  It was a discussion about marketing and the idea of engineers  leveraging for more as a community looking forwards . One  platform was mentioned here earlier that I have experience with.......and they are definitely driving value down with their marketing.  Through the history of time workers have had to fight for more (pay/benefits/better working conditions / contracts ) and imho that’s a legitimate and beneficial force in society. Noam Chomsky describes a point at which society collapses is when the imbalance of the societal structure is such that the vast majority of the workforce can no longer afford to live . In the uk we are currently experiencing strikes across many services/industries. It’s not really my way to say if they are write or wrong ......but I think the concept of unionising and leveraging for “fairer/better :::::whatever you like “ is legitimate not entitled or moany  . The suffragettes did it ......I digress. I think IME it’s a fair observation that people employed on the business side of the music business in the big music companies in the  uk work with the expectation that this will result in take home regular pay, without fear of non-payment , working with full benefits re’ holiday pay , maternity pay , etc etc.......

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've got a question for the crew that hopefully will lead to some interesting discussion but honestly could use some outside perspective here.

How important is it that we as collaborators come to a consensus on what feels good for the production of a song? Let's say you as a producer are not vibeing with the artist's direction / vision for a song, but the artist feels very passionate about their vision. You help them realize their vision all the way through and it still doesn't feel good to you or any other involved party other than the artist. What then?

I'm curious to hear some thoughts on the producer's perspective and the artist's perspective. To paint the extremes a little bit; at what point does being disagreeable as a producer (when dictated by your own taste / gut / intuition) become a hindrance to the project or unprofessional? And for the artist at what point are you getting in your own way so to speak and diminishing the potential outside contribution from collaborators that could level up your work?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Couple things from my perspective. 
1) it’s our job as producers to make the artist’s vision a winner. If we haven’t done that, we’ve failed. Like when the artist asked for a wetter vocal, we don’t just crank the verb right? We make sure it’s not causing problems mucking up transients etc. same with instrumentation and all. 
2) it’s the artist we’re serving. So when we’re done and have gotten paid, they’re the ones who have to go out and tour it, promote it, share it with they’re moms and kids and SOs etc. They need to be happy with it. 
3) if we can’t make 1 happen, we make 2 happen and move on to the next one. 

Generally I find the more I’m able to serve the artist’s vision, over time the trust grows and they become more interested and even reliant on consensus. But there are always outliers songs and outlier clients and outlier collaborators and outlier artists. 

In the long run, ain’t we all just tryna get it right?

author: Rollmottle
content: Having been on both sides of many creative endeavours, even outside the context of music, I'd like to offer one point: I don't think consensus should ever be the goal. What is "right" should always be the goal. Many creative pursuits are sullied by people wanting to be agreeable to avoid the difficult challenges and conflict that can come with trying to achieve something specific and great. Clarity of mission, buy-in to a vision and alignment on desired outcome are paramount.

author: Josh
content:
Might be a little soul crushing but he has a bigger advantage than all of us rn because of his age so it wouldn’t hurt to be a little blunt. Might get his butt in gear. But I’d basically frame it as it can’t be a career and won’t be a career until you build d the numbers. Being an artist is being a business owner. Except it’s more like owning a business that invests its money in slot machines. 

His first step is gonna be writing 100 songs. Because they’re all gonna be not that great. I think it’s important to instill the idea of not being precious with your art early on because I think we all spent way too long on that one song when we were 18 and it was awful anyway. 

Then he needs to connect with other people with the same goals as him. Find or build a community. Play shows as often as possible and see how people react to your music. Save up the little bit of money for studio time. 

After doing that for like a year or two start recording and keep networking.

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Juliette
content:
— Approach your goals with realism, always full send it and don’t be afraid to fail. 

— We’re inherently always trying to be as intimate with our craft as possible (mainly music, but also movies, chess, tech, etc.) Separate yourself from it sometimes for the sake of your love for it. Do something you hate or you’re afraid of just once and it’ll reinvigorate your existing love or gift you a feeling you’ve never had before for something new. 

— Talk to people you’ve never talked to before. Expand your community and let them be apart of your bubble. If they’re weird, you’ve got just as much right to remove them from your bubble.

author: dominic_feverspeak
content: I feel all of this. I do a lot of tracking and it’s my favorite part of the process because interacting with the musicians during the moment of capture is really exciting to me. My two cents: if there isn’t a designated producer in the room and you’re fulfilling both the engineer/producer roles then trying to get from load in to recording as quickly as possible seems to work well - that way they can be witness and collaborator to any sonic changes. Like someone was talking about a producer who just dampened the toms right away - maybe that was necessary but if the artist hasn’t heard both options in the same room on the same song then they’re left with nothing but faith that this is the right decision. But if you just start recording quickly and then chime in with “hey, I feel like maybe the toms are ringing out for too long, can we try dampening them on this next take?” They’re probably more likely to try it out.

author: Zack Hames
content:
The idea of “everything is subjective” is garbage because we live objectively. Very rarely are people simply unaffected or don’t respond to experiences. Not experiencing is still an experience.

The way you can give feedback to anything is to think about their goal or the goal of the piece. If they don’t HAVE one, then they don’t need feedback. I doubt anyone collaborating is often denying a response or feedback from another party. 

Not to mention, if a lot of people respond to something positivity or negatively, a consensus is built - usually around culture. Radio Pop music is popular because it’s approachable and simple (or appears to be) based on what our society has built into.

I’ll just stop here, this is an endless discussion. I find it frustrating to talk about because as “deep” as you can go, it feels SO surface level. but I think that’s a ME problem. Talking “Philosophy” never feels good to me personally.

author: ehutton21
content:
I feel like budgeting expenses to see what you’re actually looking at and what you actually need down to the last dollar and cent (as crazy as it sounds, it can be done fairly accurately, and some banks/creditors even provider a CVS file for excel usage of spending logs) and figuring out how to get to your breakeven point every single month eliminates a lot of angst, and often times it’s not as crazy as you think. I’m not quite in LA, my move there is next month end of September, but CoL in San Diego is nearly identical to LA in most ways. Once I put my shit into an excel spreadsheet and did the math on “this is break even; this is what it looks like if I go out every once and a while; this is what it looks like if I’m off my rocker with my credit card” I could put rather definitive numbers on things and it gave me peace of mind.

As for more of the how: I think gaming the roommate system is your best bet. I’m moving into a two bedroom place with my roommate/collaborator as well as my long time girlfriend. If you can find a way to split a bedroom, that’s gonna help. 2 bed room houses for rent aren’t that bad if you’re willing to sit down with a drink or two on Zillow for a few nights and really figure out your living area. I’ve found places for the $2300 in East LA and Pasadena. Splitting that and other key living expenses (we plan to have a few nights where we eat together and we’ll sorta rotate meal ideas, that way everyone’s not shelling out super ridiculous individual grocery charges) among 3 people each month is fairly easy so long as we hustle well.

author: ALXCPH

author: Slow Hand
content:
I continually bring them up, but I think Autechre are miles ahead of everyone when it comes to this mode of composition. They're renowned for building their own Max/MSP patches that generate complex rhythm and timbre.

They're not simply building a patch and letting it run, nor are they sequencing every single note. They're controlling the parameters at a meta level and are steering their patches. They jam and improvise and capture then they edit it into something coherent if necessary.

But not always. Sometimes they get into the weeds and give it the expert painter's touch too. They've got a collaborative relationship with their tools.

author: spectrummasters
content:
.....agreed. Im not shooting down his message. I would only have reservations around his weighting of the 40% is creation, 60% is world-building for garnering attention. Is this sustainable long term for musicians? Can you balance that much time given to your art and then even more to finding your audience?  Its an open question in my mind, partly born from having seen how musicians and djs in my community in London have quietly built lifelong careers in UKG and Drum n Bass on the back of pure devotion to their crafts and not so much pouring even more effort into self promotion. 
Its an alternative approach imho, that has now delivered a good few of them to a balanced, apparently affluent lifestyle in their 50s. Balanced as in, found the time to have children and build a private life with family as well as pursue a music career. And still going hard on the music , same as they always did.
Will Teddy Swims be burnt out at 50? Will he still love making music? 
There are quicker (and legal) ways to make money that enable us to be just as creative Giving  100% of your time to anything just to have a chance at the slim odds of making a living seems unwise imho.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm visiting New Orleans this week and the most outstanding element has - by far - been my trip to the Backstreet Cultural Museum where they display the suits of the local black masking Indians. The tribes spend all year hand sewing and beading their personal suits before they debut them on Mardis Gras and parade the streets. And then they do it all over again for the next year.

The amount of craft on display is stunning. There is a deep respect for tradition and community that runs throughout this city and it gives me chills being in the room with such wildly creative and meaningful creations. There's so much pride and tradition in everything that people do in this city, which is deeply inspiring. I really like it here.

author: MosesSOG
content:
I rather enjoy this question. Strategies to stay optimistic in 2026. 1-is a compelling vision! A a vision of the future that is exciting and has enough "impetus" or "unction" behind it to get me excited about the work i am taking on and gives me a thorough enough reason to wake up every day. 
2. - consistent prayer and a meditation practise. taking time to do things to ground my self spiritually. i also consider in thiss area study, and fasting at times, and even deliberate training and nourishment - essentially those things which benefit a spiritual life and overall well being
3. living in awe, or allowing yourself to be amazed. intentionally finding things that speak to me or captivate my mind. it is a continuous journey sometimes what used to inspire no longer does so regualy finding things that light my mind up.
4. collaboration/ contribution to a collective whole. there is nothing better than creating something awesome with afriend or brother. that is something that i do take great delight in. creating in a solitude - there is a time and place. yet if i am not connecting with people i love then it feels empty.
5. rejoice. be merry. taking time to celebrate. realizing all of this can be gone. so doing my best to keep that in my mind. there are people in much worse situations, no matter how hard it gets. and there are people who currently wish they had what i had.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Partly in light of recent Facebook… developments:

I would *very* happily leave Instagram—or make a private account and unfollow everyone except my actual friends—if I wasn’t worried that it would impact my work. I feel like I have anecdotal experience that, when I post more on Instagram, I work more. And so I keep at it even though Facebook/Instagram just generally bum me out—and are ruining society.*

I am a freelance engineer/mixer/etc. and rely almost completely on work for hire gigs, i.e. I’ve got basically no passive royalties coming in. I’ve gradually, recently gotten my name on a few bigger projects but by no means do I have random people hitting me up to work—the vast majority of my income comes from friends/acquaintances hiring me for their self-funded projects.

Has anyone else in a similar situation tried fully cutting the cord?

*BTW, this community is so rad, and I’m well aware it sprung out of Instagram. Life is complicated. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Zack Hames
content:
I didn't post on instagram from 2016 - 2021, then I started actively posting again, *strictly* about audio, music, engineering, projects. I have easily gotten 10+ projects this year from doing this. It's not all my work but it's been shockingly useful. THAT SAID, it is almost entirely from people I already knew, or friends of friends. You know this, but it's an effective way to keep YOU in people's front of mind for picking someone for a job, at least for independent projects.That's what it came down to. "Oh yeah, they are an engineer, I'll hit them up". A lot of work has been fully completed THROUGH the instagram DM's. It's genuinely insane to me but it's worked.

I think social media can and will be what you make of it. It's easy to be addicted (I definitely struggle with this) but 90% of what I am reading, ingesting, etc is all audio based. Lots of people post political stuff, news, or personal stuff and I can't entirely avoid it but for the most part I do compared to what I realize other people's feeds consist of.

I think instagram has worked for me, but it certainly won't make or break your career if you don't do good work in the first place. If you currently have 0 clients, it probably won't get you more clients. I legit think I have 300 followers which is embarrassingly low. My account is private. it still has worked for me, at this juncture in my career. I also have enjoyed the community aspect of engineers on insta and discord. 

Every interaction or project can lead to something new. That's why for a lot of people, saying "yes" to everything is the best at the beginning until you are doing so much that you have the freedom to say no.  thanks for coming to my Ted-X talk.

author: Rollmottle
content: I would always opt for no-shared walls in any scenario where I had the choice. As an LA native, both Culver City and Westchester would be relatively low on my list of places to live (I'm an Eastsider and prefer this side of town for a multitude of reasons that are probably not relevant), but between the two, I'd probably pick Culver City. You're just closer to stuff there and it's a little less of a bedroom community. Depending on where in Westchester, you also may be in the flight path of LAX so environmental noise should be a consideration as well. Depends what you're planning on doing here and where you or your wife need to be on a regular basis commute-wise. Both are relatively accessible but Culver City probably edges out Westchester for propensity to be jammed during rush hour.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: oaklandmatt
content:
it's great to be mobile and move everywhere. i do keep my vintage 87 with me at all times, so i have a solid vocal chain anywhere (apollo x preamp is more than good enough with the 87). the challenge is headphones, and i haven't found a solution that replaces speakers. i've tried some different open back headphones (grados, focal clear mg) but they don't have the "oomph" that i get from speakers. the imaging and clarity is better than my ath m50x headphones i always have, but the lack of big bass and the annoyance of open back (can't really use in public, on planes, etc) make them not really useful to me.

other than that i have a new M1 mac and can run full ableton and pro tools sessions simultaneously no problem. i can fit an apollo twin x and all the necessary cables, external keyboard, trackball, etc in a backpack. works great

author: Zach Hughes
content:
There also, in casual discussions around streaming payouts, does not seem to be much of an understanding of how the value of a stream is derived and the affect of choices made by non-music interests on that derivation.

Choices such as using a pro-rata payout model vs a user centric payout model. Spotify has said they would adopt a user centric model if the general music community called for it. This would probably be better for most of us.

Or even nuance surrounding what the definition of a stream is and consideration for the type of record being streamed relative to the payout amount. A stream of a record of complete silence is worth the same as a stream of the largest scale commercial release.

You don’t have to love the music, but if you hate every project you work on, I think burn out will be inevitable. I like the fact that you spun into a challenge and made it fun by using it as a way to learn even more. But let’s say you wanna be a mix engineer and work on hip hop. If you spend 10,000 hours only mixing country because it’s what pays. You’ll probably never end up where you wanted to go

author: Adam Thein
content:
I have quite a few collaborators who press really small amounts of vinyl (100-300) just to have it, as sort of a legitimizing thing if that makes sense.  They usually are lucky to break even on production costs.

Another challenge with vinyl is scaling up.  Lead times are insane now and you are taking a risk by not pressing enough if you have the demand there.  The hardcore fans are willing to pay and often a second hand market comes up where the price skyrockets and none of the money finds its way back to the artist.

But yeah it really is a cool artifact to me, and something worth keeping alive in my opinion.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not sure where to put this so we’ll start here and maybe we can migrate it if it lands in any way

Had a great call last week with @Josh. We talked about a bunch of stuff but one of the themes we explored was the idea that one needs a “portfolio” of slick & great sounding work to get hired

Once you’ve decided that then it becomes the focus, and changes the way things feel and the way decisions about time, who you work with etc get made. Concepts like “I’ll suck it up and work for free but *then* I will have a singular “good track” for my portfolio”. Of course there are exceptions but it feels to me that there’s something very constricting and materialist about this way of being in the world. There can be a tension between what the artist wants or what the song wants to be and what makes you look “good” in your portfolio - they want mono and grimy but you want wide/lush/impressive

In our jam I proposed a kind of thought experiment, an end of the line or extreme of the “need portfolio” way of thinking…

So let’s say you are here, a young writer, producer, mixer. You’ve been doing it 3 or 4 years. You feel that one of the reasons you are not getting hired, getting shots or getting paid well is that there isn’t a body of work for a potential client to judge you by. Ok, here’s comes the magic trick. I’m going to grant you a genie wish portfolio! 5 killer tracks with  great collaborators. Not hot 100 #1 but the kind of work that you really feel would represent you best in the world. Boom. There it is…

So now what? You get some DMs and sessions start happening. But you’re not ready. You’re not fit for game day. You’re in over your head, and don’t have the fluency, the experience, the reps and the humblings that build a great music business pro. In short you’re not ready for the opportunities the genie wish portfolio granted you

100%. In order to dissolve ourselves and enter the shared connectedness, we need to make full circle connections within ourselves. Music taught me this, especially playing for communal experiences such as Community Dance, Haitian Folkore Dance, and Churches. And we always change our state of being, we have to tune ourselves to become available over and over. I can definitely feel that I am unable to enter the connectedness when I’m not letting it happen and trying to control things. There could be all sorts of reasons for this; fear closes all circuits out of all. 

I believe this is why a lot of Eastern philosophies including Buddhism and Jainism believe in vegetarianism. Because they consider things that come from living things also part of the connectedness. 

But I cannot stop eating meat. It’s just not viable for me 😂

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Cool! Feel free to DM me as you go through this, I can probably both help and learn a bit! Re: comments, it depends on what kind of thing you're doing. If you don't want to be chronically online/focus more on music making you don't have to set a super interactive precedent. But there's real power in really engaging if that comes easy for you.

When I was doing daily youtube videos and really engaged with fans we would easily sell out big batches of merch etc. Friends with bigger numbers per video, especially if they interacted less & showed less of their personalities, had much lower conversion rates even if it might look more impressive from the outside. As often comes up in this server, it can pay to go for quality over quantity of fans, especially in the long run. But again, if you establish an interaction rate that works for you, it should be possible to make it work. You may want to consider how to connect fans to each other more instead & build a community, to the extent you can with what you're putting out

author: markmaclure
content:
Hey everyone. I’ve been doing a lot of thinking about “point of view” when it comes to artists, and I’d love to hear the community’s thoughts. 

Most successful artists (by numbers, following, cultural impact, etc) tend to have a certain point of view. It’s often somewhat broad and difficult to pinpoint  exactly what it is. Charli XCX has a song about doing cocaine at a club and a song wondering if she will run out of time to have a baby on the same album, but neither feels out of place. The Sabrina record has multiple distinct sonic landscapes within it but they feel coherent when played next to each other. “Slim Pickins” and “Bed Chem” come to mind as pretty different from each other. Post Malone and Beyoncé both went country and it seemed perfectly natural. All of these projects feel like they have a distinct point of view despite an evolving multitude of lyrical content and sonics. 

When I hear less successful artists, I often perceive a lack of a point of view. Their perspective may feel generic, it might jump around in a way that isn’t coherent, or it might not be the best representation of who they are. Sometimes the music might be coming from a genuine place and is GREAT, but it doesn’t quite land because the artist hasn’t been able to pinpoint exactly who they are sonically/lyrically/artistically and also how exactly to bring that into the world. Sometimes their preconceptions of who they are or preoccupation with a shiny new idea can get in the way too.

author: youngteam
content:
you could get lucky submitting it to someone who's openly taking submissions (timbaland's livestream for example) but you're leaving a lot up to chance and competing against a lot of people.

ultimately what you're looking for is relationships with those people you think could do it justice. cold dms sometimes work, but not guaranteed. just think how many people are sending songs to these people?

try thinking of the specific person you want to get it to, then find out all the people they work with. you're going to have to start small and work your way up the ladder of impressing people.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content: My experiences with people like this have me to currently see them as more tech-loving audiophiles than creatives. That’s fine, but the hard part comes when there’s a cognitive dissonance somewhere in the mix, especially if ego gets involved when collaborating on a creative project. Hard not to be real, but I’m also always learning so I try and give benefit of the doubt, but as I grow more and more it gets more difficult to ignore the scarcity mindset that develops from the fusion of trying to be creative, but having your neurons be so focused on the tech specs and tools needed to do so. Sad to see indeed.

author: Jasper Boogaard
content:
I’ve been that way in moments of my life for sure. Experience and collaborating with great people who do great work despite whatever gear they use were things that helped me to move past that mindset. Recognizing that the moments I was doing my best work were when I wasn’t thinking about gear at all.

More recently, this discord and the conversations podcast (specifically about the Mixdown Industrial Complex) have made this even clearer.

author: spectrummasters
content:
…yeah the independent producer community backlash has been growing for the last few years against him already . 

There’s a discussion in my wheelhouse culture at the moment (london street music creators ) about whether the real value  of a project is about numbers / popularity or moving the culture . The further the “industry “ progresses into AI , for the sake of numbers , imho the more the value moves into cultural / underground art . 
Street music stories are about a common or represented experience . We want to hear the street poetry

If you take timbos hiphop midlife crisis and combine it with soulless number based work , I don’t think it’s likely to resonate with the culture .   This is why I think he’s likely to catch an L . 

Even the new clips release is being met with , okay you’re 50 and still rapping about coke ? 

….there an element of corny creeping in as the genre ages 

On the flip side, I think a whole new genre is gonna happen soon . Where’s there’s yin there will be yang

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
- Last quick note

My business mentor saw how guilty I felt when I took breaks from ‘working’ to process mental challenges / life. I thought he’d be disappointed with my monthly update, having mostly spent time in bed processing traumas and talking to my wife about hard topics, and he said “I’m proud of you for doing the REAL work.” 

He didn’t elaborate, but I think I really get what he meant. I’ve appreciated that over these last months as I see saw between bursts of external and internal work. ❤️

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Your response had me reflecting on this, and here's my current perspective.

People spending time online debating the minuscule differences of a DAWs contribution to an export is just another one of those CLASSIC examples of people convincing themselves they are spending their time productively within their field, when they aren't.

I believe that people are most prone to externalizing once they’ve stayed in a plateau long enough. I’ve seen this happen SO many times. Skating with people who blamed losing a competition on not having hollowed trucks. Competed in Street Fighter and had an opponent that blamed the country the parts of their control stick was sourced, saying ‘If only I had ____ parts from South Korea like you…’  It’s hard to look in the mirror and go “You controlled the result. Period. No other factors. Face it. Now do what you need to improve to move forward.” Externalizing seems to be what people do when they are heavily invested in something and can’t surpass a plateau for X amount of time. I see it as more of a ‘lack of personal accountability’ problem, and that anyone can be greater at their callings, as long as they get out of their own way by not focusing their time on pointless comforts/compensations within their field.

Hopefully reflecting on this will further help me avoid time traps along the way too.

author: spectrummasters
content:
For sure , I completely agree with you that weight should be given to the apparent findings of rigorous work . Absolutely. I also think it is a disservice to all of us if people are discouraged to approach unpopular ideas and ask questions about them for fear of mockery . Or that newcomers simply accept dogma of the day . That is anti science . Our greatest scientific discoveries usually shatter the pre existing concencus view (for the benefit of all ) Newtonian physics gives way to relativity, classic physics to quantum etc . 
As you will know Cian , science is not about proving  things with absolute certainty it deals in probabilities . 
Science works to bring us to a place where we can say p< 0.05 . So imho we shouldn’t loosely  present science as absolute and unchanging truths in service of quietening and/ or deriding people and/or their ideas . 
Imho what is being missed in so doing is that it is those who dare to challenge dogma,  who challenge and constantly review empirical evidence that bring us the new discoveries . My point is less about discrediting null tests and more about celebrating people who dare to challenge dogma . And that science is also in support of those people . If young people / newcomers are to chase a few rabbit holes and cul de sacs for the will of exploration and finding things out for themselves , who would deny them that ? Those who probably did much the same thing themselves at the start of their journey into audio ? It certainly appears to be true that under observation and current technology the daws sum. Yet we are also at a moment in science where mathematicians are suggesting our reality may only be an avatar and time as a concept is outdated . In mind of these leading edges of scientific thought someone as clever as Jon challenging a consensus on nulling may or may not be genius . But laughing at or dismissing his and Aaron’s and many others sense on it …..doesn’t serve any of us imho .
